/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Please remove the notes about patch set updates and replace them with a summary of what is included in the commit itself.

Background:
The commit message is the only information that appears about the change once it is merged. If you use the 'git log' command you can see the subject line and commit message of all changes that got merged in a chronological order.

In light of the above, the commit message should describe the change that the patch delivers to help people understand the applied changes based on that summary. You do not need to include any further information beyond the description about the commit. For instance, adding notes about the changes you made between two patch sets is not informative after the patch got merged.

During the Gerrit-based code review process you always iterate on one commit and amend your change. You can easily compare two patch sets in the review system to see what got updated, but it is always the same commit.
Done

glance/api/v2/cached_images.py.message: Is this the right place to do this? I think we want to make sure there is only one caching thread per system, right? I guess I need to go look at how this is done today, but I think we want to be sure that we're not spawning N caching workers on a single node and letting them all run in parallel. Or, is there already a system-wide lock somewhere deeper?

I wonder if we really want to do this? We only need one caching thread, so no pool strictly required. Also, in the case of the eventlet execution, we might want this to run in a real thread anyway, so that we don't impact the performance of our regular activities. The caching should be totally IO-bound, so eventlet *should* work fine I think, but it might be worth considering using a regular thread always.

You need to do one of two things, either:

 1. Set daemon=True on the thread before you start it. This will 
    cause the thread to die immediately if the parent process is 
    exiting. This is how the cache thread is spawned in wsgi_app.py 
    right now.

 2. Have some sort of signal (maybe threading.Event) that this
    blocks on, or a sentinel you send down the queue, to cause this 
    loop to break. Otherwise this will continue running in the 
    background and keep us from existing without SIGKILL.

I can exit/break when queue is empty.
If I create object of normal thread and set it to True as daemon before starting the operation does not remain async and the client needs to wait until the operation completes/ i.e. it waits until image is cached completely.

(I will try to do it once again)

> I can exit/break when queue is empty.

I don't think you want to do that, do you? The queue is empty almost all of the time, but the worker should block on the queue waiting for the next thing. What you want is to signal the thread to exit (if non-daemon) explicitly. A common way to do this is to use a sentinel:

  exit_sentinel = object()
  ...
  # on exit, send the sentinel to the worker
  queue.put(exit_sentinel)

 and then in the worker:

 task = queue.get()
 if task == exit_sentinel:
     break

> If I create object of normal thread and set it to True as daemon before starting the operation does not remain async and the client needs to wait until the operation completes/ i.e. it waits until image is cached completely.

I'm not sure what you mean here. The daemon flag on the thread only affects what happens to the thread when the main process exits. If it's true, then the thread is killed immediately, and if it's false, the main process blocks on exit until the thread finishes.

You could argue that we should signal the thread to exit, and then wait for it to finish its current task before doing so. However, it would be frustrating for an operator to need to do an upgrade or patch of glance and have to wait many minutes for it to finish a cache operation before exit.

I would also put some debug in the caching thread loop as well, so you can see when it's submitted and when it is being processed/finished. Especially for verifying in gate jobs that it's happening and completing...

I think maybe my feedback got a little confused. This is creating a new queue and thread for each request, which means we could end up with a bunch of parallel competing threads, all processing a queue of a single item (followed by the inevitable exit sentinel). That's not what I intended.

I think we should:

1. Create one queue
2. Create one worker thread that processes that queue
3. Submit jobs to the queue when the API call comes in
4. Submit the exit sentinel to the thread when we need it to stop
5. Run join() to make sure it exits before we do
Made some changes and verified it works functionally. Also fixed functional tests accordingly.
DO we need to set it as daemon as well?
Daemon will make it exit with no warning if the main thread does. If you're still making the main thread signal and wait, then it doesn't matter.

glance/common/wsgi.py.message:
Regarding the graceful exit conversation:

I think probably the best thing to do is something I suggested earlier in this process, which is to make caching interruptible. That would mean we write to ${image_id}.tmp until complete and then we atomically rename ${image_id}.tmp to ${image_id} once we know it's done. On startup, we clean up any partial *.tmp files we might have left over from a previous attempt.

The other option would be to fork a cache worker process that we communicate with over a pipe and which dies with us, but I think it will be difficult to make that a true singleton amongst the workers that uwsgi forks for us. And of course, it's much more complicated.

Okay, but presumably not cleaning them up? But regardless, I think not holding up process exit for caching is probably the right thing to do. It would suck if there's a big queue of images to cache preventing you from restarting glance to apply an update. Caching is non-critical.

For the same point, an operator trying to shut down and having to wait a long time for glance to shut down because some user is downloading an image over dial-up would suck too. If we're doing a SIGHUP restart it makes sense to not drop that transfer, but waiting hours probably isn't good either.
Right, we do not clean it on startup or anytime. Agree to not hold process to exit for caching.

AFAIK we are doing the same right now, instead of storing it as tmp file we are caching the file in incomplete directory under cache folder for example for devstack the path will be /opt/stack/data/glance/cache/incomplete folder and once caching is complete we move it to upper directory.

Whether rebuilding a volume backed instance or not

the check is done in osc primarly.

strictly speaking we do not need to check the parmater here

i.e. 
        if (
            'reimage_boot_volume' in kwargs and

it would be incoreect to require the parmater in nova clint for 2.93 but we could raise an eroror as the code does below that.
it woudl be better to do that check also in osc but i was more or less ok with keeping it.

if we weant to move that check to osc which is where it really should be im ok with
that.

nova client however does at least need to allow the new microverison ot be used.

so some of this chage such as updating API_MAX_VERSION is required.

It was decided to be checked in the original design but the revision which is the Zed spec doesn't have checks on nova side. This is part of the design decision which we agreed upon to add check for this on client side and no need to check it on API side.
the requst body is not changed.

this is just asserting that you dont pass the parmater with old micorversion.s

it does not raise an error if you dont pass it for the new one because we decied that shoudl only be a clinet side check.

so it shoudl not be enforced in teh python bidnings.

this proably should pop the kwarg however.
so that its not passed  here, this is not after all a query args that is valid to pass to the api.

maybe I'm misunderstanding something, but by default we accept to reimage a boot volume with 2.93 :
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/830883/32/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py

So, here, even if someone is adding a parameter reimage_boot_volume=False, we will support it.
So, why do we need to have a specific parameter here ?

So what we have right now is
1) a client side parameter (--confirm-reimage) on the OSC side
2) No check on the API side and just passing the microversion should rebuild a volume backed instance

So if someone directly hits the API, they just need to pass the microversion 2.93 but if they request via client i.e. via the OSC client, they will need to pass both microversion 2.93 and --confirm-reimage parameter.

it is checked in osc by the way https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-openstackclient/+/831014/4/openstackclient/compute/v2/server.py#3229

Long story short I think a role that enforces openstack's commit formatting guidelines belong in an openstack role and not the generic stdlib found in zuul/zuul-jobs. Additionally, history has shown that enforcing rules like this in CI can be annoying for developers and instead reviewers might consider exercising judgement over whether a period exists at the end of a line (and by exercising judgement I mean just ignore it it isn't that big of a deal).

That said if a project really wants to enforce these rules this is probably the place to keep the role.
I agree. This ends up being a choice of using this check to spare reviewers of checking structure every time on projects that enforce it vs. not using it and be more permissive.

I agree with Clark's comments on the other patch with the same change as in this one. I remember when these formatting preferences were enforced in OpenStack, on occasions they rather made the contributor experience bad than fixing an actual issue.

I hope this change will not replace to educate contributors about the information that they should include in their commit message, as well as to pass down good practices from established contributors to newcomers!

I'm not really following the line of thought here. The aim of this check is to reduce churn on the reviews and spending reviewer time on structural issues that can be automated. 

This has nothing to do with the syntax and, specially, the semantics of what is being written on the commit message. This will still be up to the reviewers to check out and guide contributors about.

The point I was trying to make is that checks like this are incredibly frustrating to contributors because they are often trivial (like whether or not a '.' is present) and not typically checked locally before pushing due to order of operations. It isn't that reviewers need to do more work it is that they should do less and just let small things like that go by.

OpenStack does not enforce any of these rules in this way itself for these reasons. It tried to in the past using the hacking tool and it only led to problems.

I'm not a contributor to the projects that this will be applied to so I'm not really going to argue this one way or another. I just wanted you to know the history here and why something like this doesn't already exist.

A couple of nits inline.

I'm curious where you plan to use this?
I fear that few projects will use it based on previous experience, so really like to see which projects are signing up.

charm-build fails with:

metadata: Cannot read the metadata.yaml file. 

I was able to recreate that in a local build. Playing around with the src/layer.yaml, I narrowed it down to interface:designate (removing it resulted in success). In my attempt to test local changes to the designate interface, I added a build-environment directory to charmcraft.yaml with CHARM_LAYERS_DIR and CHARM_INTERFACES_DIR. What I found was that specifying any text for the value (ie. "garbage") resulted in a successful build (ie. no more complaints about reading metadata.yaml).

diff --git a/charmcraft.yaml b/charmcraft.yaml
index e8b86ef..9d56288 100644
--- a/charmcraft.yaml
+++ b/charmcraft.yaml
@@ -6,6 +6,9 @@ parts:
     plugin: reactive
     build-snaps:
       - charm
+    build-environment:
+      - CHARM_LAYERS_DIR: garbage
+      - CHARM_INTERFACES_DIR: garbage

do we know what is the root cause of the access issues? is it possible to fix the issues from the root?

My guess is that this happens because the upgrade scripts are run with root permission:

2022-08-31T21:17:54.000 controller-1 root: info 21-keystone-data-migration.sh: Starting keystone data migration from release 22.06 to 22.12 with action migrate
2022-08-31T21:17:58.000 controller-1 root: info 21-keystone-data-migration.sh: Keystone data migration finished successfully from 22.06 to 22.12

Without changing the owner to keystone, keystone-manage will create the file with root permission and keystone will fail to start with a permission error.

controllerconfig/controllerconfig/upgrad.message: Is there return value to check if the operation is successful or not?

The command doesn't return anything when it succeeds and throws an error when it does not.

The error will get logged to /var/log/platform.log if it occurs and we will not see the 'Keystone data migration finished successfully from x to y' message.

When it's a successful execution we should see only see that with no error in that same log:

2022-08-31T21:17:54.000 controller-1 root: info 21-keystone-data-migration.sh: Starting keystone data migration from release 22.06 to 22.12 with action migrate
2022-08-31T21:17:58.000 controller-1 root: info 21-keystone-data-migration.sh: Keystone data migration finished successfully from 22.06 to 22.12.
With the change on Depends-on, this line has to be replaced by chown keystone:keystone, but has to be confirmed
With the change on Depends-on, I think this line can be removed

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I agree we need unit tests and a release note. Also, please find my comments inline.

Just a side note.

I'm ok with implementing this option as the parameter is supported by Glance, but usually as long as your loadbalancer adds the proper request headers(such as X-Forwarded-For) and you enable the [oslo_middleware] enable_proxy_headers_parsing option, you don't need to give the public_endpoint option, and the actual endpoint host is automatically detected.

This setting works better especially in case you have multiple endpoints (admin, public, internal) listening at different IPs/Hosts.
Please add unit test coverage and a release note.

Thank you for your reviews.

I believe I have addressed the points you've made.  Ready for new review now! 👍

It detects the host just fine, but it's necessary when the base URL isn't /.

Example: The advertised public endpoint is https://cloud.acme.org/api/image

curl https://cloud.acme.org/api/image returns URLs that is unaware of /api/image being the base URL, (https://cloud.acme.org/v2).  Setting the option will make it behave correctly (https://cloud.acme.org/api/image/v2)

So this is necessary if you want everything to reside under a single domain for public facing traffic.
Ah, ok. That makes sense, though we might want to consider a good way to automate detection somehow.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This is a problem indeed, and charms should not really be involved in upbringing of a system.

Why not use the `iptables-persistent` / `netfilter-persistent` packages to persist the rules instead?
Hello Frode, sorry for the late response, I was on PTO. Ack, I'll submit a bare-bone, simple patch to the base charm code.

I believe the problem described here is a side effect of interaction between the system and the software managed by the charm. Many people are already hacking through it in various ways. In the end, that can lead to problems caused by these "hacks" and dialogues like, "ah yes, somebody put a NOTRACK rule in the table two years ago. That's why the connections were failing". The ability to mitigate this side effect in a controlled manner using a charm option would significantly decrease our support efforts and the number of related bug reports.

About the configuration option:
Adding a configuration option is like releasing an API, you can never stop supporting it, so I don't buy your argument. You're just putting the burden somewhere else.

The functionality you add is as we've discovered required to operate a cloud at scale and our charms should be opinionated and just do the right thing for our users. This is clearly something the end user would not want nor need to know about.

Changes in behavior like this is managed through new charm versions, tracks and channels.


About system initialization:
Just want to repeat that the charm code has to be outside the equation for bringing the system up to the expected state after a system reboot.

The charm's job is to install packages, enable configuration and services so that the system operates as expected, not be a required part of the boot process. So we either need to use one of the rule persistence services available in Ubuntu, or create some other mechanism for bringing the rule back on reboot that is independent of Juju and the charm.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hello, Mustafa,

Thank you for taking the time to work on this issue, that is much appreciated!

I have a few comments in-line and a general feedback on the approach here:
1) The organization of the ovn-chassis and ovn-dedicated-chassis charms are a bit special. This is because the charms share 99% of the code base but one is a subordinate charm while the other is a principal charm. To allow code sharing between the two, the entire chassis code base is hosted in the ovn layer hosted at [0].

This addition would be relevant for both charms, so please target that repository with your changes.

2) While I commend your effort to generalize this code, and add extra helpers to attach and detach chains etc, I wonder if this is all a bit overkill for the problem at hand?

The `nft` and `iptables` tools are quite good at finding existing rules, and the rules we need to add are quite simple.

Would it make sense to just add the rule to the PREROUTING and OUTPUT chains directly?

3) The charm should not be involved in the upbringing of the system, would it make sense to use the Ubuntu `iptables-persistent` / `netfilter-persistent` packages for taking care of system initialization instead?

src/config.yaml.message:
In essence this is a workaround for what to me appears like a long standing kernel bug.

Does this really need to be configurable at all?

Well, I'm unsure that we can consider this a kernel bug. nf_conntrack's job is to track the network flow lifecycle, so it does what it is designed for. From a networking perspective, GENEVE is altering the five-tuple that determines the "ID" of a network flow, so each flow is a `unique' network flow. As a result, nf_conntrack tracks every single GENEVE flow individually. That is not a flaw that we have in nf_conntrack. That is a flaw in how we identify unique network flows. The main problem here is that GENEVE is trying to leverage this flaw to achieve an even load distribution, which plays badly with nf_conntrack.

I wanted this feature to be behind an option flag and opt-in because it might have unintended side effects.

When everyone has to hack around this side effect, it's a clear sign there is changes needed in the kernel. It will take time but we'll eventually get this fixed there for sure.

In the mean time we do indeed need to work around this for existing users, and the best thing to do would be to make sure there chances of unintended side effects is as small as possible.

src/lib/charm/openstack/basic_ipt_helper.message:
While I commend your effort to generalize this code, and add extra helpers to attach and detach chains etc, I wonder if this is all a bit overkill for the problem at hand?

The `nft` and `iptables` tools are quite good at finding existing rules, and the rules we need to add are quite simple.

Would it make sense to just add the two rules to the PREROUTING and OUTPUT chains directly?

I wanted this design to have minimum disruption on the existing iptables layout. A dedicated chain eliminates rule duplication in tables and trivializes removing all added rules (e.g., simply detach/flush and delete the chain). The alternative is to iterate PREROUTING and OUTPUT chains, and find & erase the correct rules. The design also supports having an arbitrary number of NOTRACK rules for flexibility, so grouping them in a chain makes management more effortless. Having a dedicated chain also makes this operation transactional.

Another concern is that the user may have their NOTRACK rules in the chains (for whatever reasons), and I don't want to mess with them accidentally. I thought it would be safer to implement it this way.

Although this problem seems specific to this charm, I think it might manifest itself in other charms as well, so having a reusable code for this stuff will make porting the changes more straightforward.

For this specific use case there is very little room for variation for the rules we need to maintain, so a simple `iptables -C` call to check if the rule is already there before inserting would be sufficient. If it's there, either because we or someone else put it there, we don't need to do anything.

The charm would know what rules are needed depending on what encap the chassis uses, so there is no need for this to be configurable. At this point in time only Geneve is supported by the charms.

Thinking about future re-usability for the code is a great trait, but do wait until you actually have more than one place to use it before creating a generic reusable function/class. Otherwise you will just end up with unnecessary code to maintain (and potential bugs) if it turns out you didn't need it elsewhere.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: What's the driver for this? Undercloud has diverged from overcloud in many aspects. As there are some plans to get rid of neutron from undercloud at some point in the future, does this add any value?

> Which is also aligned with the goal that gave TripleO life. To re-use the same tools operators are familiar with to manage a cloud to also deploy clouds.

Unfortunately/fortunately, that's not true anymore and both architectures have diverged (for reasons) with ansible doing most of the heavy-lifting in the undercloud.

> Anything that helps bringing the two a little closer again should be welcomed.Resuing...

Though that was the initial goal for TripleO, lot of water has flown under the bridge and we dropped most of the services (nova, glance, mistral, zaqar, swift, keystone etc) from undercloud. The only two OpenStack services used in the undercloud atm are ironic and neutron with an ephemeral heat generating ansible configs/playbooks.

Also, as I mentioned earlier with podified control plane and EDPM(external data plan management) initiatives, UC with OpenStack services is irrelevant.

There are some next gen initiatives which will possibly get rid of the undercloud neutron (with control plane on k8s and EDPM (Data plane managed by ansible). Maybe we can wait for that rather than introducing ovn in the undercloud at this point.

Removal of Neutron from Undercloud has been talked about for a long time but not scoped with a suitable replacement yet. Since we will remove OVS before removing Neutron entirely, we should make it clear that there is more involved with transitioning from OVS to OVN in-place than simply switching the driver.

The dependency on Neutron for the undercloud is pretty lightweight. we basically just create networks and ports as an ad-hoc IP address management system. We chose Neutron for this purpose originally because it integrated well with Ironic at a time when Ironic depended on Nova networking support and was not flexible enough to use a plug-in IPAM. I think we still use the integration between Neutron and dnsmasq and/or radvd so it isn’t as simple to remove Neutron as it seems. So I think this change adds value until we have a full replacement for the Neutron/Ironic OVS stack (DHCP/PXE/tftp/http/radvd) in OVN for provisioning. There are a lot of moving parts when you consider UEFI and legacy support for provisioning.

I understand the complexities around removing neutron from undercloud. There are a few things that concern me.

1. Without having an automated migration with undercloud upgrade, how can we think of dropping OVS support(?).

2. We're trying to make undercloud as lightweight as possible with lots of effort going into it in the last few cycles to drop number of OpenStack services. Adding ovn to mix would make not help.

I wouldn't wait for that, IMO we'll still see TripleO deployments for a long time.
I'm in favor of this patch for the reasons stated by Yatin (ML2/OVN being default since Stein mainly, aligning with the deprecation plans, etcetera).

@yatin,

Is there a document that outlines the approach, next steps etc (at least a spec for tripleo changes where this can be discussed). tbh, I'm not comfortable introducing ovn in the undercloud.

> What's the driver for this? Undercloud has diverged from overcloud in many aspects. As there are some plans to get rid of neutron from undercloud at some point in the future, does this add any value?

The drive for this is the same drive that brought ML2/OVN to the overcloud, it was always the goal to have ML2/OVN in both under and overcloud. Tt wasn't done initially because ML2/OVN did not support deploying baremetal (PXE chainloading) until recently.

Which is also aligned with the goal that gave TripleO life. To re-use the same tools operators are familiar with to manage a cloud to also deploy clouds.

I don't buy the argument about the UC has diverged from OC. Anything that helps bringing the two a little closer again should be welcomed. Re-using the same components is beneficial because it makes things less complex, it share bug fixes, features are now available on both places, etc...

The plans to get rid of Neutron from the undercloud, as stated, are just plans and have been plans for years now. The plans to use ML2/OVN instead of ML2/OVS is happening right now. It's happening when Neutron accept ML2/OVN to it's code base and changed the CI to run ML2/OVN in most jobs [0], it's happening with DevStack defaulting the networking driver to ML2/OVN [1], it happening when the core OVN, Neutron and Ironic community worked together to bring baremetal support to ML2/OVN, etc... TripleO is just a part of it.  

[0] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:bp%252Fneutron-ovn-merge
[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/791436

@Rabi Your concerns are totally valid. I am not sure about the Undercloud migration plan(whether automatic during upgrade, manual or similar to overcloud migration), will need to check with other folks involved in that. But yes i can say that will and need to be cleared before dropping support for OVS.
And with plans to drop OVS we need to switch to OVN as a step till neutron is there on Undercloud. So i think we can go with the switch and take care of concerns before dropping OVS support.

@Rabi no there is no any such document, it's mostly bz https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2100403 and associated Jira tasks to track removal of ML2/OVS support, and that will cover any migration/upgrade requirement for Undercloud as without that it's not possible to drop ML2/OVS completely.

On Overcloud ML2 OVN is default since Stein release, for Undercloud this switch was pending since long to have the same networking stack, and considering the ml2/ovs deprecation plan no other alternative available this switch is needed.

What is the plan to support the migration/switch to OVN on upgrade?

The undercloud uses flat networking, no GRE or VXLAN. Is there much more to it than running neutron-ovn-db-sync-util to generate the Generates the OVN northbound database? Overcloud nodes should not require an operational undercloud to operate, so all of the br-migrate/br-int steps etc done in the OVS->OVN migration should not be required?

Won't we have to do this migration at some point anyway? If we intend to support OVS for upgraded underclouds for the forseable future is there really a reason to change to OVN for new installs?

<< What is the plan to support the migration/switch to OVN on upgrade?
This is still to be evaluated as part of https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2100403

<< The undercloud uses flat networking, no GRE or VXLAN. Is there much more to it than running neutron-ovn-db-sync-util to generate the Generates the OVN northbound database? Overcloud nodes should not require an operational undercloud to operate, so all of the br-migrate/br-int steps etc done in the OVS->OVN migration should not be required?

Yes you are right, it would be comparatively easy with less steps compared to what is done for overcloud migration. Things related to dhcp, like ports/namespaces atleast needs to be considered as part of migration, but yes all the required pieces still needs to be evaluated.

<< Won't we have to do this migration at some point anyway? If we intend to support OVS for upgraded underclouds for the forseable future is there really a reason to change to OVN for new installs?

Actually the idea to switch to OVN for new installs was to drop dependency on ml2 ovs and focus on migration bits separately, /me will not be able to comment right now on exact timeline for OVS but will follow up and track migration steps on that bz.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/mech_agent.p.message: In a routed network, all the subnets must be associated to a segment.You cannot mix with subnets not associated to segments. Doesn't this code make it possible such mixing?

Hum... yes this code is not preventing the case that you mention.

I'm wondering whether we should and how. Currently the API is providing to us that way to configure multisegments.

1 - openstack subnet create ...
2 - openstack network segment create ...
3 - openstack subnet set --segment-network ...

If we prevent this in that part I'm not sure about what will be the behavior. What do you think?
Thanks for testing it. Changing my vote

I tried it and (perhaps I missed something so would be good if somebody else can check if I understand well) but:
* I have one net, one segment (from https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-routed-networks.html )
* openstack subnet create --network multisegment1  --ip-version 4 --subnet-range 203.0.114.0/24 multisegment1-no-segment
BadRequestException: 400: Client Error for url: http://100.109.0.113:9696/networking/v2.0/subnets, All of the subnets on network '7f8d886f-cd13-450e-b1ca-ad065580c0d9' must either all be associated with segments or all not associated with any segment.

So it will not happen, and it is coming from here: https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/db/ipam_backend_mixin.py#L357 (look for SubnetsNotAllAssociatedWithSegments)

ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/utils.py.message: Lets add a salt to this? It's extremely unlikely it'd ever be seen, but why risk it? Rainbow tables are just about the only possible SHA512 attack vector...

I wonder if this is a bit too much: the example in the hashlib docs uses sha256. I'd not like it to add up to seconds for many nodes...

Also, isn't it a bit of overkill? If someone can dump the memory of the Ironic process, they can likely also access the raw redfish_address.

ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/utils.py.message: Likely overkill, but dynamically salting using the address does seem reasonable. We could use 256, but at the same time I wanted to lean towards something more secure given quantum computing is starting to see some use out there.

tobiko/tests/scenario/neutron/test_route.message:
Maybe it's better to just remove self.cleanup_stacks() here.
I'm not sure why it's called in this test.

Anyway, this patch fixes the test.

well... if I understand correctly self.setup_router() creates a new router fixture that is self.server_stack.network_stack.gateway_stack. If it is not cleaned up there will be a router configured with the server.

Proposal from Slawek:
add to the method that creates the fixtures something to force creation, even when TOBIKO_PREVENT_CREATE is True.

That's what happens during the verify-resources step. The router was created before, during the create-resources step. With this patch, the router is not created again, because the existing one is reused.

I think during create-resource, the cleanup does nothing (the resources don't exist, they don't have to be deleted). Due to that, I think the cleanup can be removed... but maybe I'm missing something.

> I think this change should enable the fstrim.timer unit and set the period to daily, instead of enabling the discard mount option

I think the question ends up being a matrix of cost versus risk. I'm thinking discard just passes the command down to the block device, but in some cases that might not work and the block unmap might just not occur.

The downside with fstrim is that could trigger at a bad time on a schedule. But I don't know what it does under the hood.

Hi Mike: I'm trying to replace the checks we have in neutron/neutron-lib of session.is_active. What we need to know is that the session has no pending commands to be execute, that the transaction has nothing to commit.

We used this logic to know if we were able or not to execute some actions (usually resource creation: ports, networks, etc). Now with this change we can have a session with a transaction active when before the transaction was not active.

Is there a way to mimic the same logic we had before now with "__autocommit=False"?
Hi Mike, can you review https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-lib/+/828738? (and the Neutron patch that depends on)

also see clarified documentation for the meaning of "is_active": https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/session_api.html#sqlalchemy.orm.Session.is_active   this attribute is only useful to detect the state where the Session has encountered an error, and will not proceed until .rollback() is called.
Done

if session.in_transaction() is False, then there are no pending operations.  as soon as a state change causes a pending operation to be present, in_transaction() is True.  This goes for non-SQL operations, like session.add(), changes on objects, etc.  it should be exactly what you want here (and certainly I was thinking about openstack-like use cases when i wrote this API):

s = Session(e)

# session starts out not in transaction
assert not s.in_transaction()

# adding objects starts the transaction
b1 = B()
a1 = A(bs=[b1])
s.add(a1)
assert s.in_transaction()

# after commit, again not in transaction
s.commit()
assert not s.in_transaction()

# changes on objects starts the transaction
a1.data = 'new data'
assert s.in_transaction()

s.commit()
assert not s.in_transaction()



The only way I can see this not being what you want, is if you want "pending operations" to be detected independently of session.begin() already being called.  if that is the case, then you want to look at session.new, session.deleted, session.dirty - if those are all empty, there should again be no pending operations.  but id assume you want to cancel the transaciton in that case - session.close() is the best way to do this without a lot of fanfare, assuming you dont need whatever state is in the session.

as of SQLAlchemy 1.4, the Session does not "begin" the transaction immediately, and instead waits until any kind of SQL is to be emitted.   that's how it resolves the original use case of "autocommit" mode, which was basically that "the user wants to be able to call the .begin() method", which you can now do so, if no transaction was begun.

To test if .begin() has already been called, either explicitly or implicitly due to SQL being emitted, use the "in_transaction" accessor, which was added to serve this use case explicitly: https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/session_api.html#sqlalchemy.orm.Session.in_transaction

oh i should clarify, that's not fully accurate if by "pending operations" you want to include state in the server-side transaction that hasn't been committed to disk yet.  if flushes have already proceeded on the Session, and it's still in_transaction(), the new/dirty/deleted collections would be clear, even though CRUD statements have been emitted which are not yet committed.  If you wanted to detect the state of previous flushes within the scope of the current transaction, you'd need to look on SessionTransaction itself at some other collections that are more private at the moment, but that still wouldn't tell you if someone emitted INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE to the database already within the database transaction (including ORM calls like query.update() / query.delete()) - there's no generalized way in place to know if a particular database transaction already in progress has changes on the database server not committed to disk yet. is_active definitely doesn't do that (it can be done using event hooks, if thats what were needed).   so not sure what it is you want to do exactly.

So this is becoming unfamiliar to me as something that was possible with autocommit=True mode.   I just re-read the 1.3.x docs for is_active, and this matches my  recollection of it, it's only going to tell you if someone called begin() or not, either explicitly or implicitly, and if the state is not in "pending rollback".  that's not really affected by "autocommit" mode for version 1.4.  Prior to 1.4, if autocommit=False, that would cause "is_active" to be true all the time because "begin" was always called immediately after Session construction and immediately after any previous transaction completed, but in 1.4 this was changed so that the is_transaction() method could be added and be meaningful.

so in 1.4, whether or not you have autocommit=True set:

s = Session()
s.in_transaction()  # -> always False
s.begin()
s.in_transaction()  # -> always True


This matches the behavior of is_active for autocommit=True.  so I maintain that in 1.4 you should be able to swap out is_active for in_transaction().

however, there is still a major behavioral change when you no longer use autocommit=True which is that the Session wont...automatically commit!  so if you have code like this

s = Session(autocommit=True)
s.add(MyObject())
s.flush()

# .. continue on and assume MyObject is persisted

that's not going to work anymore.  the above code would be changed to:

s = Session()
s.add(MyObject())
s.commit()

Similarly, any emit of ad-hoc SQL or queries will also start a transaction.  That is, if you have code like this:

s = Session(autocommit=True)
result = s.query(MyObject).all()

# .. continue on and assume no database transactions are in progress

that's also not going to work anymore.  The above code should be changed to:


s = Session(autocommit=True)
result = s.query(MyObject).all()
s.close()


So to the degree that neutron is somewhere using autocommit=True mode in that extremely legacy fashion where a Session is held opened, queries and/or flushes are emitted on it, and commit()/rollback()/close() is not called at all, that has to be changed and for the above use cases, you will see different behavior of in_transaction() because transactions are not automatically closed.
 


Anyway here is a list of the kinds of things we can detect, depending on what you want to do:

1. detect if begin() was called, either implicitly or explicitly, or not

2. detect if begin() was called as above, and whether or not an actual database transaction was started, or not.  we can do this   you can look in the SessionTransaction._connections collection for that, I can add public API.

3. detect if begin() was called, and a database transaction was started, and if any flush() calls have proceeded.  again private API I can publicize.

4. detect if begin() was called, and detect if flush() would emit SQL when next called.  use session.new/dirty/deleted, can add more convenience API for that.

5. detect if begin() was called, and whether a database transaction were started, and whether or not any SQL whatsoever were emitted on that transaction, optionally filtering for CRUD only.  This is more challenging and would require an event hook that just logs all the statements and flips on if any INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE goes over the connection.


Here's what we can't do, unless we tinkered with events and rigged up the Session to act like autocommit, which I advise against:

1. have a Session where you can run any ad-hoc SELECT, flush() or CRUD statements, and the Session is not in a transaction subsequent to that without commit()/rollback()/close() being called.


so overall I think we need to understand to what extent "autocommit" mode is being used, and if there are true "autocommit" use cases in neutron, those have to be fixed first.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Hi Alex, is this planned to change once we get the other stable branches migrated? E.g. Once stable/stein is migrated, will the stable/train origin default to bionic-train?
No particular reason for the -1. Just to raise attention on the question.

There most likely won't be a stable/stein.  The stable/train is currently proposed as the final charmhub migration and back-port target.  It will cover queens to train.  As (almost) no one will do a new install on bionic, the "train" track is for upgrades/bug-fixes on existing bionic installations, and thus the lack of a default openstack-origin (other than 'distro') won't really be an issue.

What's the -1 review for, btw?

playbooks/roles/jitsi-meet/templates/jvb.message: Do we need to template this to the individual JVB server FQDNs instead?

To enable the jvbs properly we will need to open port 9090 on each of them from meetpad.o.o, and set their server ids to their ip addresses or their fqdns so that the nginx on meetpad.o.o can proxy connections to them.

Separately the current jvb websocket port (9090) appears to be speaking http and not https. And the nginx proxy config appears to hard code http not https when talking to this port.

I think we should land this change to fix the main meetpad server which does all of its comms over localhost then look into whether or not we need to improve this deployment to have working JVBs again.
